paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Whether TRAPPIST-1 b, an Earth-sized rocky planet on a short orbit around an M dwarf, retains any atmosphere under strong stellar irradiation

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Observed system
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: one rocky exoplanet with phase-resolved thermal spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.description: TRAPPIST-1 b observed with JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy over an orbital phase curve, measuring thermal phase variation and spectral structure around the 15 um CO2 band

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Null scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Bare-rock, no-atmosphere model with minimal heat redistribution, serving as the baseline comparator for testing atmospheric presence

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere model with significant greenhouse gas absorption, particularly CO2-rich composition with moderate pressure range 0.3-1.0 bar

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Oxidized composition atmosphere model with weaker CO2 signature constraints, not fully ruled out by current data

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets
Retrieval assumptions including circulation patterns, opacity priors, and cloud treatment affect quantitative posteriors
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset
